content: The curr_chunk is a section header titled "SHORT TITLE." The "Federal Activities Inventory Reform Act of 1998" requires executive agencies to submit lists of non-inherently governmental activities annually to the Office of Management and Budget. The lists must include the fiscal year an activity first appeared, the number of full-time employees needed, and the responsible Federal Government employee. The "Federal Activities Inventory Reform Act of 1998" mandates executive agencies to submit lists of non-inherently governmental activities annually to the Office of Management and Budget. The lists include details like the fiscal year of the activity's inception, required full-time employees, and the responsible Federal Government employee. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget reviews and consults with agency heads on the final list for each fiscal year, which is then made public. The "Federal Activities Inventory Reform Act of 1998" requires executive agencies to submit lists of non-inherently governmental activities annually to the Office of Management and Budget. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget will promptly publish a notice in the Federal Register when the list is available to the public. Any changes to the list must also be made public and transmitted to Congress. Additionally, competition is required for activities on the list, with the executive agency head reviewing them within a reasonable time after publication. Under subsection (c), the head of the executive agency must review activities on the list and use a competitive process when considering contracting with a private sector source. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget will provide guidance for this process. The purpose is to determine whether to contract with a private sector source based on cost comparisons for executive agency activities on the list. The head of the executive agency must compare costs of procuring services from a private sector source with costs of performing the activity in-house. All costs, including quality assurance, technical monitoring, insurance, and overhead costs, must be considered to ensure fairness and realism. SEC. 3. CHALLENGES TO THE LIST. An interested party can challenge the omission or inclusion of an activity on a published list. An interested party is defined as a private sector source with a direct economic interest in the activity or a representative of a business association. An interested party, defined as a private sector source with a direct economic interest or a representative of a business association, can challenge the inclusion or omission of an activity on a published list. The challenge must be submitted to the executive agency within 30 days of the list's public availability. Within 28 days of receiving a challenge, an official designated by the agency head will make a decision on the challenge. Within 28 days of receiving a challenge, an official designated by the agency head must decide on the challenge and notify the party submitting it. The party has the right to appeal within 10 days to the head of the executive agency, who will then decide on the appeal within 10 days and notify the party. The head of the executive agency will decide on the appeal and send a written notification with the rationale to the party submitting the appeal. SEC. 4. APPLICABILITY. This Act applies to executive agencies including executive departments, military departments, and independent establishments, with exceptions for the General Accounting Office, Government corporations, and nonappropriated funds instrumentalities. Section 103 of title 5, United States Code defines nonappropriated funds instrumentalities as parts of departments or agencies where all employees are referred to in section 2105(c) of title 5. Certain depot-level maintenance and repair of the Department of Defense is also specified. SEC. 5. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, the term "Federal Government source" refers to any organization within an executive agency that uses Federal Government employees to perform an activity. The term "inherently governmental function" means a function that is intimately related to the public interest and requires performance by Federal Government employees, including activities that involve discretion in applying Federal Government authority or making value judgments for the Federal Government. The term "inherently governmental function" involves interpreting and executing US laws to bind the government, protect national interests, affect private individuals, control government officers, and oversee acquisitions. The term "inherently governmental function" includes directing officers, controlling property, and managing federal funds. Excluded functions involve providing advice to government officials and performing internal tasks like building security and housekeeping.
